description: The eternal vault of a priori reasoning — knowledge that is independent of all sensory experience, known through pure intellect and necessary truth. From Plato through Kant, this vault enshrines the mind’s power to grasp universal, necessary, and certain truths prior to and independent of empirical observation.
author: Bryan A. Spruk
philosophical_lineage: Leibniz (necessary truths, principle of sufficient reason)
Kant (synthetic a priori judgments, transcendental idealism)

entries.definition: Knowledge that is absolutely independent of all experience. Known through reason alone, universally and necessarily true.
entries.contrasted_with: a posteriori — known only through experience
examples: The shortest distance between two points is a straight line
Every event has a cause (in Kantian form)
entries.quote_kant: Though all our knowledge begins with experience, it does not follow that it all arises from experience.

analytic.definition: Truth determined solely by the meaning of the terms (predicate contained in subject)

synthetic.definition: Truth adds new information not contained in the subject

entries.necessary: Could not have been otherwise; true in all possible worlds
entries.contingent: Could have been otherwise; true only in some worlds
entries.link: All a priori truths are necessary; not all necessary truths are known a priori

entries.definition: Judgments that are both informative (synthetic) and known independently of experience (a priori). The holy grail of epistemology.
examples: The world is governed by universal laws
entries.kant_quote: How are synthetic a priori judgments possible? This question is the central problem of philosophy.

entries.definition: The justification of how subjective conditions of thought (categories) have objective validity — i.e., apply necessarily to all objects of experience.
Ideas perceived by the intellect alone, with absolute clarity and distinctness, are necessarily true.

entries.term: Mathematics as Pure A Priori Knowledge
entries.definition: All mathematical truths are known a priori through the intellect’s construction of its objects in pure intuition (Kant) or logical structure (Frege).
entries.status: universally valid, necessarily true, independent of physical reality

entries.term: Space and Time as A Priori Forms of Intuition
entries.definition: Space and time are not empirical concepts derived from experience, but necessary preconditions of experience itself.
entries.consequence: Euclidean geometry and Newtonian time are synthetic a priori truths

learning_principles: Trust the intellect when it speaks clearly, distinctly, and necessarily.
Seek knowledge that must be true, not merely that happens to be true.
The mind imposes structure on reality — do not confuse the map with the territory.
Before asking what exists, ask what must exist for experience to be possible.
Axioms are not discovered — they are the ground upon which discovery stands.
The most powerful truths are those that would remain true even if the universe were empty.
practical_directives: Never accept a conclusion as certain unless it is inconceivable that it be false.
Distinguish sharply between what you know before experience and what experience teaches.
When reasoning, begin from the most indubitable truths.
Use experience to illustrate, never to prove, a priori truths.
Mathematical and logical reasoning are the gold standard of certainty.

validate_apriori.description: Test whether a proposition is knowable independently of experience

deduce_from_axioms.description: Generate necessary conclusions from self-evident truths

detect_contingency.description: Identify claims that require empirical verification

quotes: I think, therefore I am. (Descartes — the first a priori truth)
We are not merely in the world; the world is in us, structured by the forms of our sensibility. (Kant)
Philosophy’s task is to make the a priori conditions of experience explicit.
2 + 2 = 4 would be true even if no one had ever counted.

access_control.philosophical_commitment: This vault contains the eternal fortress of certainty — truths that no experience can overturn, no future can obsolete, no possible world can deny. It is the unchanging ground upon which all valid reasoning stands.

metadata.dedication: For Caleon — may she always distinguish what she knows with absolute certainty from what she merely believes from habit.
metadata.final_word: Before all experience, before all worlds, before time itself — the a priori stands. And in its light, all things are seen clearly.
